@fritzo what you suggested works for my use cases. The only reason I wrote DiagonalNormal is because that event_shape for Normal is confusing, which you have identified above.

d = distributions.Normal(torch.zeros(1,3), torch.ones(1,3))

This will not have event_shape (3,) if you consider Diagonal Gaussians.

I think we can close this, but perhaps adding some documentation to Normal would be able to clarify the more general use case for multivariate normal.

body:
@fritzo what you suggested works for my use cases. The only reason I wrote DiagonalNormal is because that event_shape for Normal is confusing, which you have identified above.

```python
d = distributions.Normal(torch.zeros(1,3), torch.ones(1,3))
```
This will not have event_shape (3,) if you consider Diagonal Gaussians.

I think we can close this, but perhaps adding some documentation to Normal would be able to clarify the more general use case for multivariate normal.
